author: MoesBAR
body:
Full disclosure: these were tiny bets for fun on dirt cheap stocks in April, so short of them going out of business I knew they’d make a return.

Now most stuff is kinda overpriced so I’m just holding on to my original investments from earlier this year.

Only things I’ve bought somewhat recently are Western Digital & Seagate because I think they have great potential to sell a lot of SSD storage for the next gen of consoles and PC gamers. I got in on AMD at $55 cause they’re making the chips for PS5 and Xbox X.

I’ll trade some Roku stock here and there because they range from 140s to 170s.

Maybe I buy a little of recovery stocks that are hit really hard now or on downward days but that should recover like Coty which is at $3 and they’re a big makeup company that should do better when woman aren’t all wearing masks outside.

AGS makes gaming machines for casinos, they’re at $4, if they hit $3.8 or less that’s a buying opportunity cause they usually go back up to $4.4 and if they survive to post Covid they might be $10+ stock again.

I’m not an expert so please do your research and always diversify.

author: Endda
body:
I like STX for the dividend so it's definitely not in my portfolio as a growth play.

That said, I do agree that they need to pivot in some way. Even Western Digital has them on the tech front.

It doesn't even feel like they've capitalized on WD's recent issues as much as they could have. So yea, unless the price drops a ton, I'll keep what I have in the company for its dividend. But I'm not expecting it to go to the moon anytime soon.

author: Why_Hello_Reddit
body:
I don't know anything about ILMN. I sold a put on Intel following their drop post earnings and am bagholding them waiting for the stock to rise, so I know you pain about sudden drops.

I would say only sell the call if you want to hold and chance a rebound, and mitigate losses if you're wrong. That's all it will accomplish - reduce your losses if the stock continues to fall, and you're trading that for limiting upside should it shoot way back up, but that's less likely. At this point you're selling a lottery ticket covered by the call you already bought, so it isn't naked.

>if the price rises in a months time but not enough, and I decide to close the whole position, my sold call would further the losses?

If the price goes back up, the hedge you sell will gain in value, which isn't good as it's now worth more than what you sold it for. But, since the original call you bought is closer to the strike price than your hedge, it should go up in value even more. That's what makes spreads net positive. So if I bought a $10C and sold a $15C, and a stock rose from $5 to $8, both calls are closer to the money, so both are worth more. But the $10C is always worth more than the $15C because it's closer to the money.

>in general I get the idea that its always better to buy spreads rather than simple calls/puts because of theta etc?

Yes, I rarely buy single leg options because stocks trade in a statistical range they rarely move out of, like a bell curve, and I don't like to pay premium for theoretically unlimited profits. If TSLA has good odds to hit $550, and terrible odds of hitting $750 in a given time period, why buy a $550 call which is going to be more expensive than the $550/$750 spread? You're paying extra money for the limited chance it goes higher. And some people get really lucky, never sell and make 1000% gains. But for most people it's a waste of money which further raises the break even point.

Recently my favorite strategy is to sell puts on stock I'm long on, take the premium and buy a call spread. If I'm wrong and the stock falls, I'll sit on 100 shares and the calls expire. If I'm right and the stock takes off, the put I sold expires worthless and I get to ride free calls to tendy town. That worked great recently on WDC.

The only other time I end up with single leg options is if I buy a spread, the stock moved the wrong way, which brings the cost of the short leg hedge I sold down to nothing, and if I expect a rebound, I'll buy that hedge to close it and let the unhedged long leg ride back in the correction at a discount. But that's rare.

The only benefit of single legs is they're easier to close since you only need to sell one leg. Easy. I wouldn't trade spreads on illiquid stocks with low volume. One strike may have lots of buying and selling while the other doesn't, and your broker can't close both until they get a buy and sell on both legs, at whatever price you set. So closing spreads can be more difficult. Generally you don't need to worry on anything like AAPL.

author: LifeTaylor
body:
To be honest i have no idea what i'm doing. I have a pile of cash that was sitting around not doing anything in a savings account. Put like 20% in an index fund. 50% into companies like Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Intel, AMD, Nvidia, Sony, Nintendo, NET, Western Digital, Disney, and a few others while simultaneously dollar cost averaging down and I made a quick flip on Tesla (buying in at $330 and selling at $385 the day after)

I'm probably too late to get in on earning for this year, but nobody really knows. Tech stocks could go up another 20% before the year ends, the market could go down 20%, it could sit here idle,  like I said no one knows.

I do plan on buying into Unity this week as I enjoy video games so why not? Let me lose it all, checking stocks is the only entertaining thing in my life currently.

author: Pijoto
body: $WDC and $MU stock prices are so depressed right now, that even if there was a huge Tech crash this week, traders will probably forget these two stocks even exist. Bought 10 Jan '22 WDC $55 Calls and 4 Jan' 22 MU $60 Calls on Friday at bargain bin prices, they'll both easily meet those price targets when the Next Gen Consoles release, and drive a whole PC Upgrade Super Cycle for the next 3-5 years, get them while they're cheap!

author: thetimsterr
body: I think is this a great point and one that is possibly not being considered by the market. The demand for cloud storage is going to skyrocket in the next 5 years (more than it already has). Seems like Seagate is well-positioned to fill that demand, moreso than WDC or Toshiba.

author: LifeTaylor
body:
19% of my portfolio is in Intel.  I bought in at $48.61  

I may sell it off at some point, but its more a long-term play. Currently I think AMD (and Nvidia) are massively inflated even if they are the leaders currently and I also have stakes in them as well.

My logic may be skewed, but you know schools are giving every student a laptop..   Each one of these laptops have intel integrated graphics, which means I'm sure Intel will do fine over the next year.  Same philosophy with logitech, western digital, and seagate..   millions more computers being distributed, means that top companies that produce hard drives, Ram, CPUs, GPUs, and computer accessories are making some good profits. Not to mention gaming during a pandemic is at an all time high.

author: TrenAndOptions
body: Add STX, BA, WDC

author: Pijoto
body: Gold and Silver is a long play, probably won't pan out for awhile, but if you have the time to hold, may as well.  I'm in mostly UVXY, sold off a third of my holdings yesterday in case of dip, and glad I did, but still have 1100 worth of shares I'm riding out till the elections.  Also, have a lot of long ass dated calls in WDC and MU that expires in Jan 2022, they're both cheap AF right now, and I'm betting they'll mostly recover by then.

author: N555BAT
body:
You can save your portfolio with stocks like: CCL, DAL, ALK, WDC, INTC, JPM, AAL, JBLU, RCL and other COVID-19 depressed stocks

Personally I’m holding CCL, DAL, INTC, JPM and WDC from that list.

CCL, DAL and WDC have their dividends suspended but they’ll eventually come back.. 

Eg: CCL was paying $0.50 per quarter Div before rona. at the price right now, when they restart it will be around 13% of the $17’s, it was trading between $40-$60 before Covid

author: Pijoto
body: I've encountered wild ass swings with Options trading, from winning a cool $10G, to losing it all within months, only to gain it all back last week by betting everything I had left on UVXY shares and calls...  This shit is stressful as hell......  I'm looking to cash out most of my UVXY, I'm way too overexposed betting on a market crash that may never come, and looking to get into the selling Covered Calls game.  $WDC is a good target I figure, it's cheap with a lot of upside potential, and I figure I can earn a steady 1% a week on Covered Calls, beats the heck out of praying for Options to print.

author: dudeitsadell
body:
I'm actually bullish on semiconductors and feel like theyre the next sector to pop up... the last tech run in august was mostly cloud, aapl, tsla, internet services. Only NVDA and broadcom saw a slight bump. 

Hardware like $QRVO, $QCOM, $INTC, $AMD, $SWKS, $WDC, $MU, $TSM has some ground to make up. The sector rotation cant go to airlines or financials, so Semis and Retail it is

author: MoesBAR
body:
For their volumes I’m sure it’s significant discounts but I think their sales to PC players upgrading their systems will be much healthier margins though I’ve heard Nvidia is also releasing very impressive graphics cards at low cost so would be good to diversify in both. 

I’m also bought into Western Digital and Seagate for external flash memory storage as the spacing needs for next gen games will be huge and those are all after market so should be better margins too. 

Obviously, all of this is long term 2-3 year investments as more and more people upgrade over time.

author: bumblebear3012
body:
Right now, I am wary of the mega cap hyper growth tech trade in general although there are of course exceptions. I am more attracted to companies with exposure to the same end markets and strong competitive positioning yet with much more reasonable valuations. Intel, Micron, Western Digital, Nutanix, and HPE. 

My favorite stock right now however is a hyper growth name in Cloudflare. At around 30x sales it’s definitely not cheap, but I believe they have the best holistic approach to edge computing which is likely going to be the next generational shift like public cloud the past ten years.
